importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: ASKA Pharmaceutical filed for regulatory approval in 2024, following prescription-free trial sales of the emergency contraceptive pill, marking a key step toward over-the-counter availability.
In 2017, a health ministry panel discussed over-the-counter sales of emergency contraception, finding overwhelming public support, indicating long-standing societal demand for reform.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 marks the transition from regulatory approval to potential market launch of the over-the-counter emergency contraception pill in Japan.

keyTakeAways: Japan has approved over-the-counter access to emergency contraception for the first time, allowing women to obtain the pill without a prescription.
The pill, branded as Norlevo and containing levonorgestrel, will be labeled 'medicine requiring guidance,' meaning it must be taken in the presence of a pharmacist.
There are no age restrictions or parental consent requirements for purchase, signaling a shift toward greater accessibility, especially for younger women and rape victims.
This decision follows a 2024 trial at 145 pharmacies, where access without doctor’s supervision was tested and met with public and advocacy group scrutiny.
Japan’s traditionally conservative social norms have historically limited reproductive health access, making this reform a significant societal shift.
Emergency contraception works within 72 hours of unprotected sex, with an 80% efficacy rate when taken early, and is currently available without prescription in over 90 countries.
The approval came after years of public consultation and advocacy, with campaigners arguing that prescription barriers disproportionately affect vulnerable populations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Japan has approved the over-the-counter sale of the emergency contraceptive pill Norlevo, marking a historic shift in reproductive health policy. The decision, driven by advocacy and public consultation, removes prescription and parental consent requirements, enabling women of all ages to access the medication without medical oversight. Although the pill will still require pharmacist guidance, its availability reflects a broader societal move toward greater reproductive autonomy, especially for younger women and survivors of sexual violence. The reform follows years of debate and a 2024 trial at 145 pharmacies, and comes amid Japan’s traditionally conservative cultural and gender norms. The pill, which contains levonorgestrel and is effective up to 72 hours after unprotected sex, aligns with global standards where such contraception is already available without prescription.
title: Japan allows over-the-counter emergency contraception pill for the first time
